descriptions.content:
Grammatical gender (masculine, feminine, neuter) does not exist in Tibetan.

Articles, demonstratives, adjectives, and verbs are therefore invariable with respect to gender. Male and female sexes are, however, sometimes marked within the lexicon. This is accomplished by using distinct words, or else by means of suffixes (པ་ or པོ་ for the male and མ་ or མོ་ for the female) in the case of certain pronouns and substantives that denote animate beings.

  • གཡག་ “Yak” (male), འབྲི་ “Yak-cow” (female)
  • རྟ་ “Horse” (generic), རྒོད་མ་ “Mare”
  • བུ་ “Boy,” བུ་མོ་ “Girl”
  • ཁམས་པ་ “Man from Kham,” ཁམས་མོ་ “Woman from Kham”
  • རྣལ་འབྱོར་པ་ “Yogin,” རྣལ་འབྱོར་མ་ “Yoginī”
  • མཛོ་ “Yak/cow hybrid,” མཛོ་མོ་ “Female dzo”

Note that some pronouns make no distinction between “he” and “she”:

  • ཁོང་ཕྱུག་པོ་རེད། “He/she is rich.”
